background_dashed.customLabel: In School-age (6-12 years old),  participants, there is no difference between PUFA and controls on Overall ASD symptoms. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 7 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Pre-school (<6 years old),  participants, there is no difference between PUFA and controls on Overall ASD symptoms. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 4 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In School-age (6-12 years old),  participants, there is a small-to-moderate effect in favor of PUFA on Restricted/repetitive behaviors. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 4 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In School-age (6-12 years old),  participants, there is a small-to-moderate effect in favor of PUFA on Social-communication. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 4 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Adults (>=20 years old),  participants, there is no difference between PUFA and controls on Social-communication. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 6 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In School-age (6-12 years old),  participants, there is no difference between PUFA and controls on Acceptability. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 9 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Pre-school (<6 years old),  participants, there is no difference between PUFA and controls on Tolerability. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 3 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Pre-school (<6 years old),  participants, there is a small-to-moderate effect in favor of controls on Adaptive behaviors. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 2 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Pre-school (<6 years old),  participants, there is no difference between PUFA and controls on Language (Overall skills). Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 2 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In School-age (6-12 years old),  participants, there is a small-to-moderate effect in favor of PUFA on ADHD symptoms. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 4 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Adults (>=20 years old),  participants, there is no difference between PUFA and controls on ADHD symptoms. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 5 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Pre-school (<6 years old),  participants, there is no difference between PUFA and controls on Mood related symptoms. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 2 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In School-age (6-12 years old),  participants, there is no difference between PUFA and controls on Disruptive behaviors. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 4 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.
